Title.evidence: Quilting Technique in Mastectomy: A Stepped-Wedge Cluster Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: A stepped-wedge cluster randomised trial was conducted across 12 Dutch hospitals.

Participants.evidence: Participants were patients undergoing mastectomy without reconstruction.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention was the quilt technique, compared to conventional closure.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluated the quilt technique's impact on textbook outcomes in mastectomy patients.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was textbook outcome, defined as the absence of wound complications, readmissions, reoperations, unscheduled outpatient visits, and no increase in pain medication use 6 months post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was by cluster, with allocation concealment ensured.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not feasible for patients or clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 251 patients were included, with 179 in the quilted cohort and 72 in the non-quilted cohort.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The quilted cohort had a higher incidence of textbook outcome (65.7% vs. 41.3%, odds ratio: 2.95, 95% CI: 1.45, 6.24, P = 0.003).
